qas.question: What was the result of a child having an African mother?
What is the rule that allows children with white fathers to be slaves?
Who was the first African American to gradute from Vassar College?
What does a person have to have to be an octoroon?

answers.text: one black great-grandparent and the remainder white

plausible_answers.text: taking the status of their mothers

qas.question: What did laws from the 16th century define children of African slave mothers as?
Who was not born into slavery?
Who were free people of color in New York descended from?
Who took advantage of slave men?
What did African Americans not use passing to do?

context: Laws dating from 17th-century colonial America defined <b6_0>children of African slave mothers<b6_0/> as <b5_0>taking the status of their mothers<b5_0/>, and <a0_0>born into slavery<a0_0/> regardless of the race or status of the father, under <a1_0>partus sequitur ventrem<a1_0/>. The association of slavery with a "race" led to slavery as a racial caste. But, most families of free people of color formed in Virginia before the American Revolution were the descendants of unions between <b7_0>white women and African men<b7_0/>, who frequently worked and lived together in the looser conditions of the early colonial period. While interracial marriage was later prohibited, <b8_0>white men<b8_0/> frequently took sexual advantage of slave women, and numerous generations of multiracial children were born. By the late 1800s it had become common among African Americans to use passing to <b9_0>gain educational opportunities<b9_0/> as did the first African-American graduate of Vassar College <a2_0>Anita Florence Hemmings<a2_0/>. Some 19th-century categorization schemes defined people by proportion of African ancestry: a person whose <a3_0>parents were black and white<a3_0/> was classified as mulatto, with one black grandparent and three white as quadroon, and with <a4_0>one black great-grandparent and the remainder white<a4_0/> as octoroon. The latter categories remained within an overall black or colored category, but before the Civil War, in Virginia and some other states, a person of one-eighth or less black ancestry was legally white. Some members of these categories passed temporarily or permanently as white.
